p: Faisal I. Khan Ph.D., P.Eng. is an Associate Professor at the Memorial University of Newfoundland (St. John's, Newfoundland, A1B 3X5 Canada; Phone: (709) 737–8939; Fax: (709) 737–4042; E-mail: http://fkhan@engr.mun.ca). He is involved in research, and consulting projects related to safety and risk engineering, and process/plant integrity studies. His areas of expertise include: safety and risk engineering, risk-based integrity assessment and management, and computer aided design and evaluation of process equipment. He has authored four books, and over 150 research articles in peer reviewed journals and conferences.

p: Mahmoud Haddara Ph.D., P.Eng. is a Professor of Ocean and Naval Architectural Engineering at Memorial University of Newfoundland (St. John's, NL, Canada A1B 3X5). In addition to his interest in ship motion and stability, he has worked in the area of maintenance and risk based inspection. Professor Haddara supervised more than thirty graduate students, and authored more than 100 peer refereed publications.

p: Loganathan Krishnasamy is currently a Mechanical Engineer at Bantrel Co. Edmonton, Alberta, T6B 2X3. He is involved in the design of static, and rotating equipment. His research interests include Reliability Based Design, and optimization. He is also involved in implementing Condition Monitoring Techniques for equipment during the design stage.

authors.name: Loganathan Krishnasamy

details.abstract: This paper presents a risk-based methodology to estimate optimal inspection & maintenance intervals which maximize a system's availability. The methodology is comprised of two steps: availability modeling, and risk-based inspection & maintenance calculations. The methodology is easy to apply, and needs readily available data. The approach can be further improved by including an updating scheme based on the results of previous inspections. The proposed methodology is applied to the steam generating system of an oil fired thermal power plant. The results of the availability analysis are discussed here.
